results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part one of two and is titled ‘Festival City’. Wallace and companions travel by car to Adelaide in South Australia, filming the trip as they go.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Festival City’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:02:18:00 ‘Waterfalls Gully’ enroute to Adelaide
00:03:15:00 women posing with their cameras for the filmmaker’s camera.
00:03:39:00 women standing in front of a rock walk before climbing.
00:04:49:00 Adelaide Arts Centre.
00:05:16:00 paddle boats and fountain on the Torrens River in Adelaide.
00:06:31:00 churches in Adelaide.
00:07:09:00 camping alongside a pop-up van.
00:08:06:00 looking at an outdoor art exhibition.
00:09:42:00 sheep in a paddock.
00:10:03:00 historic ‘Peerless Roller Mills’ building in ‘Birdwood’, South Australia.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Innes National Park’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:55:00 campsite including an open fire with ‘billycan’, and a tarpaulin being set up as cover.
00:04:07:00 sign for ‘Innes National Park’
00:04:27:00 sign for ‘Shell Beach’
00:06:15:00 shifting sands in a dune.
00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows scenes from around the Northern Territory as Wallace and companions travel by car, with what appears to be camping gear packed on the roof, to Kulera, Finke River and Tempe Downs. As always, Wallace films the various landscapes as he travels.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Kulgera 168’ followed by views of the long dusty red road ahead from the moving car and a handmade sign for ‘Goody Lookout’
00:00:30:00 sign ‘Finke River’, the river and a low bridge which the travellers’ car crosses
00:01:05:00 metalwork sign for ‘NTRB Henbury Meteorites Reserve’ followed by driving scenes through dusty scrub
00:03:14:00 a hopping kangaroo and a Northern Territory magpie goose walks through long grasses
00:03:35:00 old cattleyards
00:03:45:00 Kings Canyon and many views of surrounding countryside
00:09:46:00 a golden full moon at night

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.

Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains scenes from a trip around Phillip Island in South West Gippsland, Victoria. There are many views of the beaches, rolling waves, rocks, cliffs and sand dunes. Wallace captures people strolling along the beaches and fishing from the sand with long rods, koalas and seabirds. There are some farm scenes, of children helping throw hay to cows from the back of a ‘ute’ vehicle.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:41:00 seabird snuggling in nest.
00:03:41:00 a koala up close and perched in a eucalypt tree.
00:05:26:00 visitors to the beach sitting for a chat
00:07:29:00 fishing from sand, framed by rocks
00:09:25:00 hay being distributed from a ‘ute’ (utility vehicle)

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movie Collection]

Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.title: Big brawl of '36
results.brief_description:
A personal and humorous account of a game between Benambra and Swifts Creek in 1936, where tempers flared and even the umpire was disqualified in the aftermath.

Thank you to Swifts Creek Football Club, ABC Gippsland (Photography Gerard Callinan) and Gordon Bock.

TRANSCRIPT

My first game in 1936 we had to go to Benambra and apparently there were very, very hard feelings between Swifts Creek and Benambra. It came over from the Grand Final the year before, which Swifts Creek won. I came here in September ’35 and they’re still celebrating their win against Benambra and apparently Benambra weren’t happy about it. So, I thought next year, first game next year was out at Benambra and it was sort of an evening up job…

Got to nearly half time an’ developed into a general brawl. I was playing on the wing and I was lucky, my opponent he wasn’t too keen to go in and neither was I, so we looked on. And I thought “By Jesus, they play fair dinkum over ‘ere”. I think there were over ten blokes rubbed out and I think the umpire was alto rubbed out and scrubbed. He happened to be a local bloke here, an’ he’s a great mate of mine but I’d say is the worst umpire I ever seen in my life. He completely lost control of the game altogether. One bloke got rubbed out for life, he was reported for kicking the umpire, somebody kicked the umpire and quite candidly I think he needed kicking meself. And it was in the days of the Depression and there’s a lot of Sustenance workers, Susso’s we used to call ‘em, working on the roads and that’s probably why the standard of football was very good because we had a lot of people came out into the country, poor fellows you know, that were willing to work for their keep an’ their tucker and that sort of thing…an’ they had a big Sustenance worker camp out doing up the Corryong Road and this fellow that got rubbed out for life he was one of them.

But nowadays Benambra an’ the Creek are quite good mates, we get on very well I think, don’t we?

Swifts Creek had a little Rover and apparently he had an enemy at Benambra, he was also a Rover and he said, all of a sudden there’s this bloke he’s down, see, an’ he said I was just gunna race in and slip the boot in and some dirty bugger hit me from behind.

group_siblings.title: Looking for a game at Lake Tyers

results.title: Time on for Chiltern
results.brief_description:
Accounts of the famous 1954 Grand Final between Chiltern and Greta, where time stood still in the fourth quarter and controversy reigned forever after.

Thank you to Chiltern Football Club, Tom Greenaway, Don Stephenson, Kevin Mayhew and the newspaper room at the State Library of Victoria.

TRANSCRIPT

[CLOCK TICKING]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

DON STEPHENSON: I came to Chiltern in 1950. And in the famous ‘54 Grand Final, I was the center half forward. The next year, we made the Grand Final and lost to Greta after 43 minutes elapsed in the last quarter. That sounds unbelievable, but it’s a fact.

[CLOCK TICKING]

KEVIN MAYHEW: At three-quarter time, we held a fairly comfortable lead. However, something happened in the timekeeper’s box. And something that even to this day, we’re not too sure, whether it was a Bermuda triangle or a vortex that come over the timekeeper’s box at Tarrawingee, we can’t say.

But as the game unfolded in the final quarter, Chiltern maintained their lead. And as legend would have it, at the end of full time, the Swans were actually in front on the scoreboard. The siren didn’t sound at the end of full time. It actually went into overtime. And at the end of time on, Chiltern were still in front on the scoreboard.

[CLOCK TICKING]

DON STEPHENSON: My immediate oponent, Ernie Ford, said to me around that time, he said, well, you’ve done us to a bloody frazzle Don, so good on you. And we just kept going, and I laughed, and I said, oh, it’s going to go any second. But it just failed to go.

After 35 minutes, cars were leaving the ground in droves and we were four goals in front. And I blame ourselves, up to a point. I think we sort of relaxed, thinking the game was won.

And one bloke by the name of Gordon Byron drove into Wangaratta, through he’d switch on the wireless and see what the final score was. And to his amazement, the game was still going. Which he couldn’t believe. And at the final siren, we had the ball in our forward line, of but we lost the game by four points.

[BUZZER]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

KEVIN MAYHEW: There are many theories— and some, you would suggest, might be conspiracy theories— as to why the final quarter went for almost as long as the previous three quarters in total.

[CLOCK TICKING]

Over the next 39 years, Chiltern and Greta would be known as traditional rivals, all because of what happened on the Grand Final day in 1954.

[BUZZER]

[CROWD CHEERING]

DON STEPHENSON: We even made up a little ditty on Greta, you know? We had, Greta in the morning, Greta in the evening, Greta at suppertime. We’ll eat those purple people. We’ll eat them any old time. It’s a good story, and it’s true.

DON STEPHENSON: I came to Chiltern in 1950. And in the famous ‘54 Grand Final, I was the center half forward. The next year, we made the Grand Final and lost to Greta after 43 minutes elapsed in the last quarter. That sounds unbelievable, but it’s a fact.

[CLOCK TICKING]

KEVIN MAYHEW: At three-quarter time, we held a fairly comfortable lead. However, something happened in the timekeeper’s box. And something that even to this day, we’re not too sure, whether it was a Bermuda triangle or a vortex that come over the timekeeper’s box at Tarrawingee, we can’t say.

But as the game unfolded in the final quarter, Chiltern maintained their lead. And as legend would have it, at the end of full time, the Swans were actually in front on the scoreboard. The siren didn’t sound at the end of full time. It actually went into overtime. And at the end of time on, Chiltern were still in front on the scoreboard.

[CLOCK TICKING]

DON STEPHENSON: My immediate oponent, Ernie Ford, said to me around that time, he said, well, you’ve done us to a bloody frazzle Don, so good on you. And we just kept going, and I laughed, and I said, oh, it’s going to go any second. But it just failed to go.

After 35 minutes, cars were leaving the ground in droves and we were four goals in front. And I blame ourselves, up to a point. I think we sort of relaxed, thinking the game was won.

And one bloke by the name of Gordon Byron drove into Wangaratta, through he’d switch on the wireless and see what the final score was. And to his amazement, the game was still going. Which he couldn’t believe. And at the final siren, we had the ball in our forward line, of but we lost the game by four points.

[BUZZER]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

KEVIN MAYHEW: There are many theories— and some, you would suggest, might be conspiracy theories— as to why the final quarter went for almost as long as the previous three quarters in total.

[CLOCK TICKING]

Over the next 39 years, Chiltern and Greta would be known as traditional rivals, all because of what happened on the Grand Final day in 1954.

[BUZZER]

[CROWD CHEERING]

DON STEPHENSON: We even made up a little ditty on Greta, you know? We had, Greta in the morning, Greta in the evening, Greta at suppertime. We’ll eat those purple people. We’ll eat them any old time. It’s a good story, and it’s true.
description_for_label:
Accounts of the famous 1954 Grand Final between Chiltern and Greta, where time stood still in the fourth quarter and controversy reigned forever after.

Thank you to Chiltern Football Club, Tom Greenaway, Don Stephenson, Kevin Mayhew and the newspaper room at the State Library of Victoria.

TRANSCRIPT

[CLOCK TICKING]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

The siren didn’t sound at the end of full time. It actually went into overtime. And at the end of time on, Chiltern were still in front on the scoreboard.

[CLOCK TICKING]

DON STEPHENSON: My immediate oponent, Ernie Ford, said to me around that time, he said, well, you’ve done us to a bloody frazzle Don, so good on you. And we just kept going, and I laughed, and I said, oh, it’s going to go any second. But it just failed to go.

After 35 minutes, cars were leaving the ground in droves and we were four goals in front. And I blame ourselves, up to a point. I think we sort of relaxed, thinking the game was won.

And one bloke by the name of Gordon Byron drove into Wangaratta, through he’d switch on the wireless and see what the final score was. And to his amazement, the game was still going. Which he couldn’t believe. And at the final siren, we had the ball in our forward line, of but we lost the game by four points.

[BUZZER]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

[BUZZER]

[CROWD CHEERING]
